citation.article-title: Staphylococcus lugdunensis sp. nov. and Staphylococcus schleiferi sp. nov., two new species from human clinical specimens.

p.s: Description of Staphylococcus schleiferi sp. nov.
Staphylococcus schleiferi (Latin genitive form of Schleifer. The name honors Karl Heinz Schleifer, German microbiologist, for his many contributions to the taxonomy of gram-positive organisms)
The description is based on 12 strains.
Cells are gram-positive cocci; 0.8 to 1.0 μm in diameter; nonmotile and nonsporeforming; occurring singly, in pairs, small clusters, or chains composed of three to seven cells.
Colonies on P agar are 3 to 5 mm in diameter after 4 days of incubation, nonpigmented, smooth and glossy, and slightly convex, with regular edges.
Good growth on 10% NaCl.
Weak growth on 15% NaCl after 4 days.
Homogeneous and heavy growth in brain heart broth at 30 to 45°C.
Weaker growth in 3 days at 20°C.
Good growth in both the aerobic and the anaerobic parts of thioglycolate medium.
In thioglycolate broth, the predominant acid is L-lactic acid.
Weak hemolysis on sheep blood agar after 2 days; no hemolysis on rabbit blood agar.
Catalase produced.
Oxidase test negative.
Coagulase test negative with both rabbit plasma and bovine plasma.
Staphylokinase not produced.
The heat-stable nuclease produced is not inhibited by anti-S. aureus deoxyribonuclease serum.
Arginine dihydrolase test positive.
Ornithine not decarboxylated.
Acetoin produced from pyruvate.
Alkaline phosphatase produced.
N-Acetylglucosaminidase test weakly positive.
Acid produced from D-glucose, D-mannose, and glycerol.
Acid not produced from maltose, lactose, sucrose, turanose, D-mannitol, D-raffinose, D-ribose, L-arabinose, D-cellobiose, D-xylose, xylitol, α-methyl-D-glucoside, and D-melibiose.
Esculin, f3-glucuronide, and L-arginine acrylamide not hydrolyzed.
Urea not hydrolyzed.
Enterotoxins A, B, and C, TSST-1 toxin, and exfoliatin toxin not produced.
Susceptible to 25 μg of lysostaphin per ml.
Resistant to 400 μg of lysozyme per ml.
Resistant to the vibriostatic compound O/129 and to bacitracin.
Susceptible to 0.12 μg of novobiocin per ml.

Susceptibility to the following antibiotics is similar to that of S. aureus ATCC 29213 (minimal inhibitory concentrations given in parentheses): penicillin G (0.06 μg/ml), oxacillin (0.12 to 0.25 μg/ml), gentamicin (below 0.06 μg/ml), kanamycin (0.5 μg/ml), amikacin (0.25 to 0.5 μg/ml), chloramphenicol(2 μg/ml), tetracycline (0.12 to 0.25 μg/ml), erythromycin (below 0.06 μg/ml), clindamycin (below 0.06 μg/ml), rifampin (below 0.06 μg/ml), vancomycin (0.50 to 1 μg/ml), pefloxacin (1 μg/ml), fosfomycin (0.12 to 2 μg/ml), nitrofurantoin (2.5 to 5 μg/ml), and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (1 to 4 μg/ml).
The peptidoglycan structure is of the L-Lys-Gly5-6-Ser0.2-0.3type.
The cell wall teichoic acids contain glycerol, glucose, and glucosamine.
There is no β-ribitol teichoic acid or protein A.
The type strain is strain N850274 (= ATCC 43808).
Description of the type strain.
Strain N850274T was isolated from a catheter.
The type strain has all the characteristics given for the species.

In addition, it has the following properties: nitrate reduced; pyrrolidonylaminopeptide and 2-naphthyl-β-D-galactopyranoside hydrolyzed; clumping factor produced; acid weakly produced from fructose; no acid produced from trehalose.
Gelatin not hydrolyzed.
Not typable by the International Basic Set of S. aureus phages. S. aureus antigen a5/i1i2.
The G+C content of DNA is 37 mol%.
